text: most Chinese economists agree that there
is a reform deficit in China that China
needs some kind of reforms if it's going
to move to the next level of economic
development there's a need to liberalize
the banking system to reduce the power
of state enterprises the question for
she and his team is do they have the
political capital to push this through
against very strong vested interests
China has very powerful state companies
for example in natural resources energy
banking these are all basically one
hundred percent in state control they
are not going to want to see their quasi
monopolies or oligarchies challenged by
more market-driven reforms and yet it's
exactly these kind of reforms that
people think are necessary for China to
take the next step she rose through his
career in the eastern mostly in the
eastern provinces of China where there
was an emphasis on economic growth and
trying to open up business and commerce
to the outside world he spent much of
his time in Fujian province which did a
lot of trade with Taiwan and with
Taiwanese business interests and was one
of the more liberal pot provinces in
terms of economic policy Xi Jinping is
quite unusual he's been to the United
States three times so he has more of a
sense of what America was about them
previous leaders the big question is
will he be tougher with the United
States or will he try and restore a
relationship that is on friendlier terms
Xi Jinping's coming to power just as
China is involved in a very nasty spat
with Japan and has been involved with
quarrels in the South China Sea I think
we can expect Xi Jinping to be very
tough with the Japanese and equally on
the South China Sea he's not going to
give an inch and this may be the era
where we see China exerting its power in
its near
alone
